  \cellcolor{green!27}\small As a linguist, I'd say we are justified in ignoring the dictionary here. Dictionary semantics is about reducing usage down to the smallest number of necessary and sufficient features, but linguistic terms and categories do not always develop around necessary and sufficient features, and for abstractions, they rarely ever develop that way. Additionally, dictionaries don't adjudicate meaning, they just try hard to keep up with it. Their treatment of "\textbf{racism}" has been historically inaccurate, and in no small part because the people who have written and edited dictionaries have overwhelmingly been wealthy white people. "\textbf{Racism}" was historically used to refer to the oppression of a weaker class by a more powerful class. The first known usage refers to the US government's oppressive treatment of Native Americans, and that's actually the primary context for the term for many years. During the Civil Rights Movement, white people began to fight back against the movement by accusing \textbf{black} people of being prejudiced, but because \textbf{racism} was always about power against a lack of power, they invented the term "reverse \textbf{racism}." This referred to racial prejudice from less powerful groups against more powerful groups, but it was a laughable bit of rhetoric that has never gained much support anywhere. White people continue to seek to undermine equality by dismissing the highlighting of oppression as \textbf{racism} on the part of \textbf{black} people, but now they just use the term "\textbf{racism}" all by itself, insisting it refers generically to any racial prejudice. This not only helps to undercut the ways white people and institutions are prejudiced, but it also mitigates the seriousness of racial prejudice on the part of white people by tacitly insisting it is the equivalent of racial prejudice on the part of \textbf{black} people. \textbf{Black} people have for years highlighted this historical usage and expressed concern for a more accurate definition of the term, but they don't have the institutional power to effect that kind of change yet. Importantly, white people insisting \textbf{racism} is generic prejudice over and against the argument that it is about power is precisely an example of a more powerful group using their power to silence and marginalize the concerns and opinions of less powerful groups. In other words, it is the very definition of \textbf{racism}.\normalsize   & \cellcolor{green!27}Black, Racism & \cellcolor{green!27}Ethnicity - Black, Ethnicity - General & \cellcolor{green!27}12/377 & \cellcolor{green!27}3.183 \\  \hline

  \cellcolor{green!27}\small The definition of \textbf{racism} that combines power and prejudice comes from David Wellman's book entitled 'Portraits of white \textbf{racism}' (1993), and was later included in 'The Blackwell Dictionary of Sociology' by Allen G. Johnson. Personally, I think it's ridiculous to conflate and merge the traditional definition and Wellman's definition into one. And I say this as a passionate student of sociology. Because there are clearly different forms of \textbf{racism}. In recent years Institutional \textbf{racism} ["prejudice \& systematic power"] has been progressively reduced to a certain degree here in the western world. It is however still a very real problem so I do feel there is a place for this definition. But to claim that it's the best or the only definition - while trying to replace the traditional definition with the term "racial Prejudice" - is, in my view, both misguided and potentially dangerous. Now, it's important to note here that Wellman never personally stated that \textbf{black} people can't be \textbf{racist}. However, it cannot be denied that the way in which his definition was included in the Blackwell Dictionary of Sociology left the door wide open for such subjective interpretations and claims. I do not believe this was intentional but I do think it was irresponsible. It would've made far more sense to include both definitions separately, rather than simply conflating the two.\normalsize   & \cellcolor{green!27}Black, Racism, Racist & \cellcolor{green!27}Ethnicity - Black, Ethnicity - General & \cellcolor{green!27}5/223 & \cellcolor{green!27}2.242 \\  \hline

  \cellcolor{green!5}\small Okay, I know your talking about things from an American perspective, but I'm curious about how that correlation between \textbf{race} and power works when you take into account class.In the UK you can have swaiths of white people (most notably skin-head extreme right-wingers) who say lots of things based on racial prejudiced against \textbf{black}, eastern European, Islamic groups but they as a group (as a class) don't even come close to having any kind of power over these groups.   \cellcolor{green!5}\small \@bruno Hey Bruno, thanks for responding. This youtube channel is for MTV USA so it has no obligation or authority to speak about racial divides in other countries - especially because other people are already addressing it elsewhere. I highly recommend Cecile Emeke's "Strolling" and "FLaner" series as well as Hairunruled's series "Pretty" for \textbf{black} identity in Europe perspectives. These are conversations with people of colour living in Europe and how the perceive the world differently. No one has denied the differences in racial politics. And while I understand the class issues of the UK to a certain extent, brought to a height in the early Industrial \textbf{Age}, it is merely an aspect of what human valuation does to various groups. Whiteness has extended over time to include various groups that previously were not considered so. But it is still an ethnocentrism that only see humanity and value in likeness, in in-group factors. This then branches out to \textbf{racism} in a very ugly way when you have a convenient marker for discrimination. The UK's class issues and feudal mentality has always been a precursor to \textbf{racism}. It was a driving factor because here you didn't have to do any pesky work to examine clothes, mannerisms and manner of speaking before knowing if you were better than somebody, you merely had to look at their face. Eventually the distinction between the Irish, Northerners and poor whites versus POC became wider because you had a convenient underclass that would pass it on to their children and just announce their inferiority into eternity. How nice. It is all interlinked and one does not forgive or eliminate the other - one further entrenches the other. It's all about the valuation of life as more or less worthwhile based on accidents of birth. It's all wrong, but it's not all equally damaging. And one group can still inflict harm on another despite both being on the lower end of society.However, I doubt we're disagreeing about anything here :)\normalsize   & \cellcolor{green!5}Age, Black, Racism & \cellcolor{green!5}Age - General, Ethnicity - Black, Ethnicity - General & \cellcolor{green!5}4/334 & \cellcolor{green!5}1.198 \\  \hline
  \cellcolor{green!27}\small \@AleyaMusic Hi Aleya, thanks for you response.First let me claify, I'm talking in a contemporary sense and though we can't ignore the atrocities of colonialism - and indeed when we talk of modern \textbf{racism} we have to take colonialism into account. We can't begin to understand the place of Pakistani people, or \textbf{Indian} people in the UK without the tool of post-colonialism.Also let me say that class in the UK isn't just money. It's identity, deep rooted. In fact I would say it resembles a 'Caste' in India than the USA's notion of class. Put this another way - Robbie Williams and David Beckham are both working class people, despite the fact they have millions of pounds. I hope that makes sense.With those point in mind because I didn't make them that clear in my first comment, I'm not talking about poverty or being poor. I'm talking about class identity's intersection with \textbf{race}. We have \textbf{racism} - we do, I'd be the first to admit that - but, that's not what I'm trying to criticise. I'm trying to narrowly ask the question of the conflation between power and \textbf{race} is a functional dynamic to understand \textbf{racism} outside of the USA (or 'new world' countries).I don't believe that lower class Brits see themselves in the 'same group' of politicians or people with power. This has added emphasis when we take Wales and Scotland into account, but its the middle-classes, the south, Londoners that have the power. Yes there is a dynamic of \textbf{race} and power if we consider two middle-class people that are white and an \textbf{ethnic} minority. But, that's by the by.The UK has a troubling history of 'white supremacy' but it's not the 'whiteness' that makes the 'white man' supreme. It's the middle-class features of the man - his literacy, his involvement with law, his religiosity, his church, his queen and country, his empire on his map in his drawing room. One only has to look to the work houses, prohibition movements, 'charities', conception of poor life that lead to a call for the 'edification of in the working class' in the 1800s that ran alongside colonialism to see that there is a hell of a difference. If it wasn't for labour and the trade unionists the brutalities against the working class, the north, wales and Scotland would have been much worse and lasted much longer - not to mention the 1st World War and 'lions led by donkeys'. The foot soldiers were often middle-class kids come out of Sandhurst, because the working classes in the \textbf{Black} Country, in Wales, in the North were in the mines digging up the coal to run the empire of the middle class, so they could feed there kids. Look at how UKIP is gaining power - it is a middle-class 'empowering' a un-powered working people to be against immigration and instilling \textbf{racism}.So consequently, the correlation between \textbf{race} and power that is comfortable in an American setting becomes, in light of this, much more troubling and complex.What does this mean for \textbf{racism} in the UK? Well it's very different from the USA. All Asian (in a british context this means middle eastern, as opposed to far eastern or \textbf{Indian} which would fall into a different category because language) or \textbf{Black} British people account for 7, whereas Latino and \textbf{Black} people make up nearly 30 of the American population. This means that issues of \textbf{race} are focused around cities - particularly London. It also means (especially when you consider the impact of post-colonial immigrants to the UK from Africa and Jamaica) that \textbf{black} identity isn't defined by slavery in the same way as in the states. This, I want to clarify doesn't mean that Slavery isn't an important historical thing to address, it just filters into British society differently. So the American power dynamic between 'white slave owner - \textbf{Black} slave' is either not present or completely re-figured. So British racial issues are for the most part tied up with immigration, Islamophobia, against white eastern Europeans and gypsies. These aren't necessarily power related issues. Yes, we still have a disproportionate amount of representation in the commons but again, that way of measuring power is a very American democratic tool, and doesn't account for local politics. And because our minority  is much lower the disparity is less. The difference between 5 of non-white representatives and 12 of non-whites, or even the previously mentioned 7 of Asian and \textbf{Black} British (the two most deprived groups), is a heck of a difference from the power differential between a nearly 90 white congress with a 30 non-white population. So when you measure 'Prime Ministers' by racial standards - even if there was perfect representation and ignoring all other contributing factors such as serving on the cabinet, shadow cabinet, publicity, relationship to previous PMs- you would have a 1 in 10 chance of having a minority leader. That's not to say we shouldn't support minority MPs not at all, but we have a different history, ethnography and domestic interpersonal relationship with ourselves to understand \textbf{racism} through.This leads me to my concluding point. Britain has \textbf{racism}, it would be absurd and morally dubious to deny that. But Britain (and so to the rest of the world, especially Europe) needs to understand \textbf{racism} on its own terms, with its own history, with its own ethnography, with the impact it has on its people. America has dominated the discussion of \textbf{race} - and for good outcomes, and for a good results. But we need to start realising that these assumptions that we make about \textbf{racism} that apply so easily, usefully and brilliantly in an American setting don't simply apply across the pond. The relationship between \textbf{race} and power is one such example - we need to be more nuanced in terms of our history, our society. It's so easy to assume because we share a language the UK is just an America further east, or vice versa. But we have very very different ways of seeing the world (and that's great!), and our social justice systems and arguments both coming from America to a global audience, and to the UK from a global meeting point, need to recognise and be able to have the tools to adjust accordingly. We need to be more relativistic about \textbf{race}, give more voices to people of colour in our country, and see the nuances of being non-american.I'll leave with this amazing quote from Akala, south London rap artist whom I adore. \textbf{Racism} exists, but it intersects and needs to be understood along with the broad, deep and dynamic history of Class and the affects of classicism.But in reality you have more in \textbf{common} with immigrants ,Than with your leaders I know, both side of my family \textbf{Black} and white are fed ghetto mentality Reality in this system, Poor people are dirt regardless of shade But with that said, Let's not pretend that everything is the same- Fire in the Booth, Akala\normalsize   & \cellcolor{green!27}Black, Common, Ethnic, Indian, Race, Racism & \cellcolor{green!27}Ethnicity - Black, Ethnicity - General, Ethnicity - Native-American, Social Class - Working class & \cellcolor{green!27}29/1178 & \cellcolor{green!27}2.462 \\  \hline
